docs.snippet: SMALL--Abe, died peacefully in his sleep on January 31st, 2013 in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn where he lived most of his 97 years. Born Abraham Smolowitz on December 9th, 1915 in a LES tenement apartment to Jewish immigrants Ida and Sam Smolowitz. Mo...
docs.lead_paragraph: SMALL--Abe, died peacefully in his sleep on January 31st, 2013 in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn where he lived most of his 97 years. Born Abraham Smolowitz on December 9th, 1915 in a LES tenement apartment to Jewish immigrants Ida and Sam Smolowitz. Mother Ida was a seamstress at the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory, but as fate would have it she stayed home to care for her ill sister the day the factory burned down. Ida went on to marry Sam Smolowitz. They had three children David, Abe and Dorothy. Abe spent his formative years in Bensonhurst. Intelligent and curious, Abe graduated from New Utrecht High School and went on to Brooklyn College. As a devoted son, Abe left university to help his father run the family store on Orchard Street. At 26, Abe enlisted in the army. He was a proud member and decorated officer of the 3158th Signal Core, 45th infantry division. Before going overseas, Abe married his girlfriend Jean Shankman on April 14th, 1943. Three years later Abe returned home to his wife and the family store, but eventually made his career as a traveling salesman and garment expert in the tri-state area. If you needed directions from Brighton Beach to Sleepy Hollow, Abe was your guy. Three children later, he and Jean were settled in Sheepshead Bay, where they happily remained until his death. A devoted man to family and friends, Abe was greatly engaged in his faith and his community. His extensive work with the Shore Park Jewish Center, B'Nai Brith, Brooklyn College Hillel, UJA and his 20 years of service with the Brooklyn Veterans Hospital will long outlive him. Keeping up with the weather, the news, and his responsibilities as a US citizen, Abe read the New York Times front to back every day, and always exercised his right to vote. He cast his last vote (November 2012) at 96 years old. He loved baseball, black cherry ice cream, going to shul, the beach, the state of Israel, a good bargain, a good movie, a good debate, and his grandchildren. His sharp mind and memory never left him. He is survived by his wife Jean, 93, his sister Dorothy, 94, nieces and nephews, cousins, his three children, Barbara Callaghan, Paul Small, Gay Abrams, five grandchildren, and four great- grandchildren. He adored his granddaughter Robin, who sadly predeceased him. Abe leaves a legacy of a strong moral compass and a life well-lived. The unveiling of his monument will take place this Sunday, April 27th at 11am at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York.

docs.snippet: The stewards of golf might want to think twice before tinkering with the golf hole....
docs.lead_paragraph: The stewards of golf might want to think twice before tinkering with the golf hole.
docs.abstract: News analysis; proposal by TaylorMade-Adidas Golf, manufacturer of golf equipment, to make the hole in golf the size of a birdbath or small foxhole stems from worry that game is too hard to play and is rapidly losing participants; difficulty of the game may, on the other hand, be a large part of its appeal for those who do play.

headline.main: A Birdbath-Size Hole and the Future of Golf
headline.print_headline: A Birdbath-Size Hole and the Future of Golf

docs.abstract: Stuart Miller travel article on a family hiking trip to Wrangell-St Elias National Park and Preserve; one of Alaska's most vital treasures but also one of least-visited national parks, park offers exhilarating climbs and mesmerizing glacial views.

headline.main: Ice Climbing in an Alaskan Glacial Paradise
headline.print_headline: Ice Climbing in a Glacial Paradise

docs.snippet: The young man, who is accused of killing a classmate at a high school on the morning of the junior prom, is being held at a medical facility under psychiatric evaluation, his lawyer said....
docs.lead_paragraph: The young man, who is accused of killing a classmate at a high school on the morning of the junior prom, is being held at a medical facility under psychiatric evaluation, his lawyer said.
docs.abstract: Students and faculty at Jonathan Law High School in Milford, Conn, are struggling to make sense of incident in which junior Chris Plaskon fatally stabbed classmate Maren Sanchez; both students are described as being popular; some speculate as to whether Sanchez's rejection of Plaskon's invitation to the prom was involved.

headline.main: Suspect in Stabbing at Connecticut School Is Described as Popular
headline.print_headline: Suspect in Stabbing at Connecticut School Is Described as Popular

byline.contributor: Nate Schweber reported from Milford, Conn., and Michael Schwirtz from New York. Alison Leigh Cowan, Elizabeth Maker, Daniel E. Slotnik and Vivian Yee contributed reporting.
